docs.title: Crux Notes
docs.text: Knowledge and stories for climbers by climbers.

docs.title: What you will find
docs.text:
• Climbing advice and knowledge based on books and official resources.
  • Blog posts and stories from climbers who’ve been through their own crux moments.
  • Gear reviews based on personal opinions.

docs.title: Join the project
docs.text: This website is open source. If you have your own story to share or any feedback, contributions are more than welcome!

docs.title: Welcome to Crux Notes
docs.text: This website contains climbing tips based on climbing books and other official resources.

docs.title: The goal
docs.text: To find something useful or at least relatable, regardless of your climbing experience.

docs.title: What's inside?
docs.text:
• Climbing knowledge from trusted resources.
  • Stories from fellow climbers who want to share their journeys and experience.

docs.title: Open source
docs.text: This is an open source project. Feel free to contribute on GitHub if you want!

docs.title: Code of conduct
docs.text:
Welcome to Crux Notes. This project is open source, and contributions are welcome.

To keep things respectful and productive, we ask all contributors to follow this Code of Conduct.

docs.title: ✅ Be respectful
docs.text:
• Assume good intent, and engage with kindness.
  • Constructive feedback is welcome — personal attacks or dismissive behavior are not.
  • Treat contributors with empathy and patience.

docs.title: ✅ Stay climbing-focused
docs.text:
• Keep your contributions relevant to climbing knowledge, training and related experiences.
  • Avoid unrelated content, self-promotion, or spam.

docs.title: 🚫 Not allowed
docs.text:
• Harassment, hate speech, or discriminatory remarks.
  • Trolling, sarcasm aimed at individuals, or gatekeeping behavior.
  • Plagiarism or submitting copyrighted material without permission.

docs.title: 🛠 Reporting issues
docs.text: If you notice any behavior or content that violates this code of conduct, please open an issue or contact the maintainers.

docs.title: 💛 Let's climb better, together
docs.text:
Crux Notes exists to help climbers learn and share knowledge. Let’s build a space that encourages curiosity, generosity, and good climbing ethics.

Thanks for being here!

docs.title: How to Contribute
docs.text: First of all, we’re really happy that you want to contribute to Crux Notes! Your help makes this climbing resource more useful, accurate, and enjoyable for climbers of all levels. Your contributions are welcome!

docs.title: Do you have content to contribute or found a mistake?
docs.text:
You can contribute by one of the following options:

  1. Opening a pull request on GitHub Fork the repo, make your changes, and open a pull request. This lets you contribute your own tips and knowledge easily.

  2. Opening a GitHub issue Share your ideas or content proposals, and we’ll work together to integrate them.

  3. Not familiar with GitHub? No problem! You can reach out to us!

docs.title: How to run the project locally
docs.text:
Before running the project locally, make sure you have the following installed on your system:

  • Python 3
  • Git

Then clome the repository: 

git clone https://github.com/tsolakoua/crux-notes.git
cd crux-notes

Create your virtual environment and install the dependences:

python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt

Run the server:

mkdocs serve

Now you can go to http://127.0.0.1:8000 and check out the website.

docs.title: Strength training for performance
docs.text: Based on The science of climbing training: An evidence-based guide to improving your climbing performance by Sergio Consuegra.

docs.title: Definitions
docs.text:
RE (Repetition effort)

Number of repetitions performed relative to the maximum possible. For example, an RE of 8 (out of 12) means 8 repetitions were completed when 12 could have been done, leaving 4 reps in reserve.

%1RM (Percentage of one repetition maximum)

Percentage of the maximum weight a person can lift once with proper technique.

Velocity loss

Reduction in execution speed during a set, expressed as a percentage.

docs.title: Repetitions
docs.text:
These guidelines help adjust your training load according to whether you are a beginner, intermediate, or advanced climber.

Level Velocity loss RE (Repetition effort) %1RM Beginners 10–20% 8 (out of 20) to 6 (out of 12) 57% – 70% Intermediates 10–25% 8 (out of 18) to 4–5 (out of 7–8) 57% – 80% Advanced 15–25% 8 (out of 16) to 1–3 (out of 2–4) 60% – 90%

docs.title: Exercises
docs.text: Upper Body Core Lower Body Bench press Plank Barbell squat Push ups plus (brench press alt) Pallof press Deadlift Dips plus Toes to bar Romanian deadlift Military press Knees to elbows Nordic curl Pull-ups Abd-wheel Razor curl Barbell row Front lever Bulgarian split squat Face pull Farmer walk Step up Glute bridge Pistol squat Superman on all fours Calf raises Cat camel Soleus
